metadata.titleEn: Greenland ice sheet surface melting 0.05 ˚ Daily data sets (1985, 2000, 2015)
metadata.description: Surface melting is the primary reason that affects the mass balance of Greenland ice sheet. At the same time, ice and snow have high albedo, and  ice sheet surface melting will cause the difference of radiation energy budget, and then affects the energy exchange between sea-land-air. The high-resolution ice sheet surface melting product provides important information support for the study of Greenland ice sheet surface melting and its response to global climate change. This dataset combined microwave radiometer product and optical albedo product, the daily, winter (June-August) averages and July averages of the former are used for layer-stacking, then Gram-Schmidt Spectral Sharpening was adapted to fuse the layer-stacking results with MODIS GLASS albedo product. The spatial resolution of fusion-results has been downscaled from 25 km to 0.05˚. By employing a threshold-based melt detection approach for each fusion-results pixel, Greenland ice sheet surface melt daily product for 1985, 2000, 2015 (DSSMIS) was generated. The spatial resolution of DSSMIS is higher than that of published data sets at home and abroad. Combined with the advantages of radiometer and albedo data, the spatial details characteristics are enhanced and consistent with the extraction range of the original radiometer products, effectively reducing the noise of the radiometer. DSSMIS’s data type is integer, where 1 is melted, 0 is not melted, 255 is masked area besides Greenland ice sheet, and the data set is stored as *.nc.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the surface melting data is stored in NC format. The file name is "antarcticcdailysurfacemeltyyyy-yyyy. NC", where yyyy-yyyy represents the year. For example, ‘antarcticcdailysurfacemelt1985-1986.nc’ represents the NC file, which describes the surface melting range of the Antarctic ice sheet from July 1, 1985 to June 30, 1986. The NC file contains four variables: melt and polar_ Stereographic, x and y, respectively represent the melting pixel value, coordinate system information, X coordinate and Y coordinate in the projection coordinate system.

Data reading method: all NC files in the dataset can be directly read by panoply program （https://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/panoply/download/ ）, select the variable melt , create the XY coordinate axis corresponding to the variable x and variable y for browsing, and change the time to browse the melting range of different dates. If you want to save it as a separate picture for display or analysis, you can use the "multidimensional tool - create NetCDF grid layer" tool in ArcGIS program to process the results and generate a file in TIF format, including the melting range of all days in the corresponding year. You can change the display time by opening "enable time in this layer" in the "attribute - time" tab. In addition, you can also select GDAL, NCO, CDO and other tools to open NC files or convert them to other formats.

background: Understanding surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS) is important for evaluating the effect of the changing global climate on humanity, and for forecasting sea level rise. Global sea levels are rising, and current predictions suggest that the rate of sea level rise will continue to accelerate. Mass loss of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS) currently contributes about 0.72 mm/yr to global sea level rise, and along with Antarctica, is predicted to become the dominant contributor to global sea level rise within the century. The mass balance quantifies the total mass change of the GrIS and is directly proportional to mean global sea level. It has been shown that the rate of GrIS mass loss is increasing and could contribute to 7-21 cm increase in Global Mean Sea Level (GMSL) by the end of the century. Both the Surface Mass Balance (SMB) and glacier discharge (ice deposited from outlet glaciers directly into the ocean) contribute significantly to the mass balance of the GrIS, and the two are correlated. The SMB includes positive mass contributions from precipitation as well as loss due to evaporation and sublimation in addition to the dominant meltwater runoff loss. Current forecasts, which include uncertainties in basal friction, the lubrication of discharging ice, suggest large uncertainty in the future Greenland mass balance. Accurate knowledge of the current state of the GrIS SMB is thus imperative to predict the possible rate of future global sea level rise. Surface mass loss is expected to increase significantly in the 21st century, compared to discharge, and the SMB is the dominant contributor to uncertainty in GMSL predictions. One of the most direct methods of measuring mass change is by gravimetry from the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) satellite. GRACE-derived estimates have their own sources of uncertainty, particularly glacier isostatic adjustment or postglacial rebound and tidal aliasing. Also GRACE measurements typically need more than 5 years of integration to achieve sufficiently accurate estimates of GrIS mass-change. Mass balance can also be studied from laser or radar altimetry but these techniques also have uncertainties introduced by the required knowledge on density distribution over the GrIS. Satellite data have been used to map surface melt on the GrIS, particularly passive microwave, radar backscatter, and visible imagery. However, these methods only provide maps of binary information on melt versus non-melt, and are unable to provide quantitative information about volumetric liquid water. In Houtz et al. (2019) a new method was introduced for the simultaneous retrieval of snow/firn mass-density and snow liquid water content from passive L-band radiometry.
research objective: We demonstrate a recently developed L-band passive microwave algorithm for the retrieval of snow liquid water and snow and firn density over the GrIS. In this study, we expand corresponding retrievals to the entire GrIS, and show: density, liquid water column, and integrated surface liquid water estimates. We show that liquid water column, down to the penetration depth of L-band microwaves, can be calculated from SMOS-based retrievals using a physically deterministic Emission Model (EM). By integrating retrieved liquid water over time and area we estimate the volume of melt water on the GrIS as a function of time and as an annual total. We discuss how this quantified total melt water relates to the GrIS surface mass loss and thus to the SMB, and we also discuss the limitations of the algorithm and uncertainty contributions.
challenges: GRACE-derived estimates have their own sources of uncertainty, particularly glacier isostatic adjustment or postglacial rebound and tidal aliasing. Also GRACE measurements typically need more than 5 years of integration to achieve sufficiently accurate estimates of GrIS mass-change. Mass balance can also be studied from laser or radar altimetry but these techniques also have uncertainties introduced by the required knowledge on density distribution over the GrIS. We discuss how this quantified total melt water relates to the GrIS surface mass loss and thus to the SMB, and we also discuss the limitations of the algorithm and uncertainty contributions.
methods: The resulting SMOS-based WS retrievals are used to quantify liquid water over the GrIS resulting from surface melt of the uppermost firn/snow layer. Here, T0 is computed for each year individually, as opposed to the multi-year mean used in Houtz et al. 2019, to demonstrate a more operationally-ready algorithm. We also only consider a period in the assumed dry snow period (the first 90 Days of the Year (DoY)) in which we assume the firn/snow to be dry, as surface wetness can significantly increase the firn/snow permittivity and therefore change the Brewster angle. For a SMOS orbit i the instantaneous water column at a single pixel Wc, i can be calculated as: Wc , i = WS ⋅ twet. The instantaneous water column Wc, i can now be summed over all observations, and normalized by the number of observations, to obtain annual (yr) liquid water column Wc, yr. The value of Wc, yr is computed for each GrIS pixel on the SMOS Equal-Area Scalable Earth version 2.0 grid (EASE-grid 2.0) (Brodzik et al. 2012).
dataset: The retrievals are performed using brightness temperatures from the ESA SMOS satellite. Microwave brightness temperatures measured at 1.4 GHz by the European Space Agency (ESA) Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) satellite are the sole input to our retrieval algorithm.
findings: The integrated annual surface liquid water retrieved over the entire ice sheet compares on the same order as modeled estimates of total meltwater available in current literature. The density retrievals show potential for mapping the equilibrium line altitude of the ice sheet by determining where retrieved densities exceed typical seasonal snowpack density, thus indicating the presence of firn.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that improves spatial resolution for studying Greenland Ice Sheet surface melt?
Example.Answer: A data collection method that improves spatial resolution involves using microwave radiometer and optical albedo products. These are combined using the Gram-Schmidt method to enhance spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚, allowing for detailed analysis of surface melt patterns.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data to map surface melt on the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Example.Answer: One challenge is that satellite data often only provide binary maps of melt versus non-melt, lacking quantitative information about volumetric liquid water. This limits the ability to fully understand meltwater dynamics and its contribution to surface mass loss.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that has been used to retrieve snow liquid water content over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for this purpose is from the ESA SMOS satellite, which provides microwave brightness temperatures measured at 1.4 GHz. This data is used in an algorithm to retrieve snow liquid water content and density over the Greenland Ice Sheet.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using microwave radiometry in data collection for surface melt analytics over ice sheets?
Definition.Answer: Microwave radiometry, particularly from satellites like the SMOS, is significant in surface melt analytics over ice sheets as it provides brightness temperature measurements that can be used to retrieve snow liquid water and snow and firn density. This method allows for the analysis of liquid water resulting from surface melt, which is essential to understanding the surface mass balance and the contribution to global sea level rise.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with gravimetry-based methods for measuring mass change in ice sheets?
Definition.Answer: Gravimetry-based methods, such as those using the GRACE satellite, face challenges like uncertainties due to glacier isostatic adjustment or postglacial rebound, tidal aliasing, and the requirement of more than five years of data integration to achieve accurate estimates of ice sheet mass change. These challenges can affect the precision of mass balance studies.

Definition.Question: How does the integration of passive microwave data with optical albedo products improve dataset resolution in ice sheet surface melt studies?
Definition.Answer: The integration of passive microwave data with optical albedo products, such as using the Gram-Schmidt method, improves dataset resolution by enhancing the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. This fusion captures clearer spatial details and maintains the dynamic range of the original radiometric data, effectively suppressing noise and improving the accuracy of surface melt detection over ice sheets.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet using microwave radiometry compare to those using gravimetry from the GRACE satellite?
Comparison.Answer: Microwave radiometry, as used for surface melt detection, provides high-resolution spatial data by integrating microwave radiometer data with optical reflectance products, enabling detailed mapping of melt areas. In contrast, gravimetry from the GRACE satellite measures mass changes over time and requires longer integration periods (more than 5 years) to achieve accurate estimates, due to uncertainties like glacier isostatic adjustment and tidal aliasing.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial resolution and data type between datasets derived from microwave radiometry and those from laser or radar altimetry for studying the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets derived from microwave radiometry, as mentioned, have a spatial resolution of 0.05˚ and provide binary data indicating melt or non-melt areas. On the other hand, laser or radar altimetry datasets typically offer different spatial resolutions and include quantitative altimetric measurements to assess changes in ice sheet elevation, which can be affected by uncertainties in density distribution.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do passive microwave methods for retrieving snow liquid water content differ from methods using visible imagery in evaluating the Greenland Ice Sheet's surface melt?
Comparison.Answer: Passive microwave methods for retrieving snow liquid water content, such as those using L-band microwaves, provide quantitative estimates of liquid water volume and density over time and area, allowing detailed understanding of meltwater contributions. Visible imagery, however, primarily offers binary maps of melt versus non-melt without quantitative volumetric information, limiting its ability to assess the total meltwater content.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of high-resolution satellite data improve the understanding of surface melt patterns on the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of microwave radiometer and optical albedo products can enhance spatial resolution, providing clearer spatial details of surface melt patterns. This method allows for a better response to surface melt dynamics and helps in reducing noise in radiometer data, leading to more accurate datasets.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise from using satellite-derived measurements to infer surface mass changes on the Greenland Ice Sheet, and how might these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include uncertainties from glacier isostatic adjustment, postglacial rebound, and tidal aliasing in GRACE data, as well as density distribution knowledge for altimetry. Addressing these could involve refining measurement techniques, using longer integration periods, or integrating multiple data sources for cross-validation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the high resolution improvement in datasets dealing with surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high resolution improvement in datasets dealing with surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet is caused by the fusion of microwave radiometer band composite data and MODIS GLASS albedo products using the Gram-Schmidt method, which enhances the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are there uncertainties in current methods for estimating the mass change of the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in current methods for estimating the mass change of the Greenland Ice Sheet arise from factors such as glacier isostatic adjustment or postglacial rebound and tidal aliasing in GRACE-derived estimates, as well as the required knowledge on density distribution over the ice sheet in laser or radar altimetry techniques.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately quantifying volumetric liquid water on the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in accurately quantifying volumetric liquid water on the Greenland Ice Sheet are contributed by the limitations of satellite methods used to map surface melt, which typically provide only binary information on melt versus non-melt, and the uncertainties in the retrieval algorithms that estimate snow liquid water and snow and firn density.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does integrating multiple satellite data sources have on the spatial resolution and accuracy of ice sheet surface melt datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating data from microwave radiometers and optical reflectance products enhances spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚, providing clearer spatial details and maintaining the dynamic range of the original radiometer products while suppressing noise, thus improving the accuracy of surface melt detection.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of different satellite-derived data methods affect the estimation of surface mass loss in the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Different satellite-derived methods, such as passive microwave, radar backscatter, and visible imagery, provide only binary information on melt versus non-melt, lacking quantitative volumetric information. In contrast, using passive L-band radiometry can offer simultaneous retrieval of snow/firn mass-density and snow liquid water content, allowing for more detailed estimations of surface mass loss.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of generating a high-resolution surface melt product over the Greenland Ice Sheet using microwave radiometer and optical albedo products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to provide important information for studying the surface melt of the Greenland Ice Sheet and its response to global climate change by improving spatial resolution to 0.05˚, allowing for clearer spatial detail and effective noise suppression.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to develop an L-band passive microwave algorithm for retrieving snow liquid water and firn density over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing this algorithm is significant because it allows for the retrieval of snow liquid water and firn density over the Greenland Ice Sheet, which helps quantify the volume of meltwater and understand its relation to surface mass loss and surface mass balance, contributing to predictions of future global sea level rise.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using brightness temperatures from the SMOS satellite as the sole input for a retrieval algorithm over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to quantify liquid water over the Greenland Ice Sheet resulting from surface melt, which is critical for understanding surface mass loss, and to provide accurate data that can be used to estimate annual liquid water columns and support assessments of the ice sheet's impact on global sea level rise.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in enhancing the spatial resolution of ice sheet surface melt datasets using satellite data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To enhance the spatial resolution of ice sheet surface melt datasets, the process involves using a combination of microwave radiometer and optical albedo products. The Gram-Schmidt method is applied to combine microwave radiometer band data with MODIS GLASS albedo products, increasing the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. This approach also includes using threshold methods based on the difference in brightness temperature between daily and winter measurements to extract surface melt data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are liquid water and density retrievals from snow and firn conducted over the Greenland Ice Sheet using passive microwave algorithms?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Liquid water and density retrievals are conducted by applying an L-band passive microwave algorithm using brightness temperatures from the ESA SMOS satellite. The algorithm calculates the liquid water column down to the penetration depth of L-band microwaves using a physically deterministic Emission Model. The retrievals are performed for each pixel on the Greenland Ice Sheet using brightness temperature measurements at 1.4 GHz, leading to estimates of the volume of melt water over time and area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges associated with using GRACE satellite data for measuring mass change over the Greenland Ice Sheet, and how do these challenges affect the data collection process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges associated with using GRACE satellite data include uncertainties related to glacier isostatic adjustment or postglacial rebound and tidal aliasing. Additionally, GRACE measurements require more than 5 years of integration to achieve accurate estimates of mass change. These challenges affect the data collection process by introducing uncertainties in mass balance studies and necessitating long-term data collection and integration to produce reliable results.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the enhancement of spatial resolution in datasets concerning the Greenland Ice Sheet surface melt?
Enablement.Answer: The enhancement of spatial resolution is achieved by using the Gram-Schmidt method to fuse microwave radiometer data with MODIS GLASS albedo products, improving the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚.

Enablement.Question: How do certain satellite technologies enable the retrieval of snow liquid water content over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Enablement.Answer: The ESA SMOS satellite, through its microwave brightness temperatures at 1.4 GHz, enables the retrieval of snow liquid water content by using a physically deterministic Emission Model (EM) to calculate the liquid water column over time.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are associated with using gravimetry from satellites like GRACE in obtaining accurate mass-change estimates for the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include uncertainties such as glacier isostatic adjustment, postglacial rebound, and tidal aliasing, which require more than 5 years of integration for sufficiently accurate estimates.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving high spatial resolution in datasets that map surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Expectation.Answer: Achieving high spatial resolution can be challenging due to the need to integrate data from different sources, such as microwave radiometers and optical reflectance products, which have varying resolutions. The fusion of these data types to enhance spatial resolution requires sophisticated methods like the Gram-Schmidt process, and this integration can be affected by noise and other uncertainties inherent in the original datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why do some data collection methods struggle to provide quantitative information about the volumetric liquid water in the Greenland Ice Sheet?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional satellite data collection methods like passive microwave, radar backscatter, and visible imagery typically deliver binary maps indicating melt versus non-melt conditions, but they lack the capability to quantify volumetric liquid water. These methods are limited in their ability to penetrate the snow and firn layers deeply enough to assess the liquid water content accurately.

Expectation.Question: Why might the retrieval of snow liquid water and density over the Greenland Ice Sheet face uncertainties and limitations?
Expectation.Answer: The retrieval of snow liquid water and density faces uncertainties due to factors such as glacier isostatic adjustment, postglacial rebound, and tidal aliasing, which affect GRACE-derived estimates. Additionally, satellite measurements require more than five years of integration to achieve accurate mass-change estimates, and variations in snow and firn density contribute further challenges to precise retrievals.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using microwave radiometry and optical albedo products in enhancing spatial resolution for ice sheet surface melt datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of microwave radiometry and optical albedo products is deemed effective in enhancing spatial resolution for ice sheet surface melt datasets. By employing the Gram-Schmidt method, the integration of these products raises the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚, providing clearer spatial detail and maintaining the dynamic range of the original radiometer products while effectively suppressing noise.

Assertion.Answer: The integration involves using the Gram-Schmidt method to combine microwave radiometer data with MODIS GLASS albedo products, which improves spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. The method synthesizes the microwave radiometer bands with the optical data to achieve finer spatial detail while maintaining the dynamic range of the original radiometer data.

Additionally, methods like passive microwave, radar backscatter, and visible imagery provide only binary melt/non-melt maps without quantitative volumetric information.

Assertion.Answer: Quantifying the liquid water column is crucial as it helps estimate the volume of meltwater over time and area, which relates to the Greenland Ice Sheet's surface mass loss. This information is essential for understanding the Surface Mass Balance (SMB) and its contribution to global sea level rise predictions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges faced in deriving accurate mass balance estimates for the Greenland Ice Sheet and discuss how these challenges impact data collection and analysis.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in deriving mass balance estimates include uncertainties from glacier isostatic adjustment, postglacial rebound, and tidal aliasing, especially in GRACE-derived estimates which require long integration periods for accuracy. Laser and radar altimetry also present challenges due to uncertainties in density distribution knowledge over the ice sheet. These challenges impact data collection by introducing significant uncertainty in mass change measurements, affecting the reliability of predictions related to global sea level rise.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used to estimate snow liquid water content and firn density over the Greenland Ice Sheet and discuss their implications for understanding surface mass loss.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods involve using a recently developed L-band passive microwave algorithm to retrieve snow liquid water and firn density over the Greenland Ice Sheet. The approach employs brightness temperatures from the SMOS satellite and a physically deterministic Emission Model to estimate liquid water columns. These methods provide a way to quantify surface mass loss more directly and relate it to Surface Mass Balance, contributing to a better understanding of mass changes and their implications for sea level rise.
